metadata.sermon_title: Epiphany: Judges 6:1–23; Psalm 111:10; Luke 5:1–11 / Baptism of the Lord: Isaiah 42:1–9
metadata.sermon_start_end: The combination of heavenly grace and earthly fear is one of the most powerful recurrent themes in Scripture. Sometimes the word “fear” in English means something more like “reverence” or “awe,” but very often it means just plain “terror” or “dread.” [...] where the promises of God break through to the exiles, where even the smallest acts of human charity signify the coming of the time when the dead will be raised, and all our sins and foolishness will be no more.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker’s primary requirement of focusing on ONE specific passage. It treats two distinct liturgical occasions (Epiphany and Baptism of the Lord) and multiple texts (Judges, Luke, Isaiah). It speaks about 'themes' (fear, hope) rather than the unique, unrepeatable word of a single pericope.
quotes: Today we have two readings about the fear of the Lord, one from the Old Testament and one from the New.
Two stories: one about Gideon, one about Peter.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either the Gideon or the Peter narrative and isolate what that specific text says about God that no other text says, rather than harmonizing them into a general theme of 'fear'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is basic narrative exposition, particularly regarding the Babylonian exile and the Midianite threat. However, it lacks the depth of linguistic or theological rigor Dekker expects from one trained in Hebrew and Greek. It remains at the level of storytelling.
quotes: This hopelessness must have assailed the people of Israel during the time of the Babylonian exile in the fourth century BC.
Gideon, an untried young man of no distinction from a small Hebrew tribe...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exegetical tension. For example, explore the specific theological weight of 'Shalom' in the Gideon text or the specific 'newness' in Isaiah's Hebrew context.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest part. The preacher connects the biblical text to concrete contemporary realities (crack addiction, income tax, subways). It avoids purely general 'truths' by grounding them in modern life feelings.
quotes: while we are about our mundane daily lives, cleaning our nets, threshing our wheat, doing our income tax, riding the subway...
The young woman who lives in the Port Authority Bus Terminal has been a crack addict...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application arises strictly from the *specific* text rather than using the text as a springboard for a general illustration about grace.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a traditional 'block' structure: first the story, then the meaning. The hearer is not consistently 'expounded' alongside the text; rather, the text is explained and then applied at the end of each section.
quotes: Two stories: one about Gideon, one about Peter. God draws near to them both... [Application follows]
Here is an image. The young woman who lives in the Port Authority Bus Terminal...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Mix the contemporary reality into the narrative of the text itself so the relevance is immediate, not a post-script.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The 'three parts' are present in the background. Misery is addressed as sin and hopelessness, and redemption is clearly outside the self. However, the 'gratitude' (sanctification) part is less developed, leaning more on the 'event' of grace.
quotes: You and I are deep in sin. We clutch our privileges to ourselves...
He does not ask us what we are doing to make ourselves better; he just gives the gift.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Strengthen the 'gratitude' aspect by showing how this 'holy dread' specifically reshapes the life of the believer in the world.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions being 'lost,' but it lacks the 'seriousness of choice' Dekker demands. The 'two ways' are blurred by a focus on the 'irruption of grace' that seems to happen regardless of the human subject's responsibility.
quotes: If your rebelliousness and mine were allowed to play themselves out to the end, we would be lost...
He does not ask if we are working to turn ourselves around... he puts redemption into our blanket.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the hearer as a 'willing and responsible being.' What is the consequence of refusing the 'Fear not'?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: The sermon is clearly Christocentric. Christ is the telos, and the doctrine of the two natures is implicit in the discussion of God becoming man and being 'dunked' in the Jordan. Grace is central.
quotes: God has become man. Yahweh... has come down in the person of his Son...
The ultimate glory of God is to be brought about by the ultimate sacrifice.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Connect the specific Old Testament texts more rigorously to Christ without falling into generalities.

8_depth_and_length.findings: The estimated duration is approximately 14-15 minutes. According to Dekker, a sermon less than 20 minutes cannot achieve the necessary breadth for depth. It is too brief for the multiple texts it attempts to cover.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the length to at least 20 minutes by deepening the exposition of a single text rather than skimming over several.

overall_assessment.summary: The text falls short of Dekker’s definition primarily due to its lack of focus on a single Bible passage and its insufficient length. It functions more as a thematic reflection on 'Epiphany' than a specific exposition. While the contemporary application is concrete and the Christology is sound, the 'two ways' and the specific uniqueness of the text are neglected.
strengths: Concrete application to modern life (e.g., crack addiction, daily chores).
Clear Christocentric focus where grace is an external gift (extra nos).
Effective use of 'holy dread' as a psychological and theological category.
weaknesses: Lack of a single specific pericope (Thesis 1.3).
Weak emphasis on human responsibility and the 'two ways' (Thesis 6).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the strict sense of Dekker’s theses. It is a thematic address. To become a sermon, it must abandon its multi-text approach, focus on the 'nowhere else' of one passage, and expand its depth to exceed 20 minutes.
